026/**
027 * A text generator for producing sentences and/or words in nonsense languages that fit a theme. This does not use an
028 * existing word list as a basis for its output, so it may or may not produce existing words occasionally, but you can
029 * safely assume it won't generate a meaningful sentence except in the absolute unlikeliest of cases.
030 * <br>
031 * This supports a lot of language styles in predefined constants. There's a registry of these constants in
032 * {@link #registered} and their names in {@link #registeredNames}, plus the languages that would make sense for
033 * real-world cultures to use (and all use the Latin alphabet, so they can be swapped around) are in
034 * {@link #romanizedHumanLanguages}. You can make a new language with a constructor, but it's pretty time-consuming; the
035 * recommended ways are generating a random language with {@link #randomLanguage(long)} (when you don't care too much
036 * about exactly how it should sound), or blending two or more languages with {@link #mixAll(Object...)} or
037 * {@link #mix(double, FakeLanguageGen, double, Object...)} (when you have a sound in mind that isn't quite met by an
038 * existing language).
039 * <br>
040 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 11/29/2015.
041 * @see NaturalLanguageCipher NaturalLanguageCipher uses a FakeLanguageGen to reversibly translate English text to nonsense.
042 * @see Thesaurus Thesaurus uses this class a lot to generate things like plant names and the titles of nations.
043 */
044public class FakeLanguageGen implements Serializable {
045    private static final long serialVersionUID = -2396642435461186352L;
046    public final String[] openingVowels, midVowels, openingConsonants, midConsonants, closingConsonants,
047            vowelSplitters, closingSyllables;
048    public final boolean clean;
049    public final double[] syllableFrequencies;
050    protected final double totalSyllableFrequency;
051    public final double syllableBias;
052    public final double vowelStartFrequency, vowelEndFrequency, vowelSplitFrequency, syllableEndFrequency;
053    public final Pattern[] sanityChecks;
054    public final ArrayList<Modifier> modifiers;
055    public static final GWTRNG srng = new GWTRNG();
056    private static final OrderedMap<String, FakeLanguageGen> registry = new OrderedMap<>(64, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
057    protected String summary;
058    protected String name = "Nameless Language";
059    private static final transient StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(20);
060    private static final transient StringBuilder ender = new StringBuilder(12);
061    private static final transient StringBuilder ssb = new StringBuilder(80);
062    /**
063     * A pattern String that will match any vowel FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box, including Latin, Greek,
064     * and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
065     */
066    public static final String anyVowel = "[àáâãäåæāăǎąǻǽaèéêëēĕėęěeìíîïĩīĭįǐıiòóôõöøōŏőǒœǿoùúûüũūŭůǔűųuýÿŷỳyαοειυωаеёийоуъыэюя]",
067    /**
068     * A pattern String that will match one or more of any vowels FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box, including
069     * Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in 
070     * {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
071     */
072    anyVowelCluster = anyVowel + '+',
073    /**
074     * A pattern String that will match any consonant FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box, including Latin,
075     * Greek, and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in
076     * {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
077     */
078    anyConsonant = "[bcçćĉċčdþðďđfgĝğġģhĥħjĵȷkķlĺļľŀłmnñńņňŋpqrŕŗřsśŝşšștţťțvwŵẁẃẅxyýÿŷỳzźżžρσζτκχνθμπψβλγφξςбвгдклпрстфхцжмнзчшщ]",
079    /**
080     * A pattern String that will match one or more of any consonants FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box,
081     * including Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in
082     * {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
083     */
084    anyConsonantCluster = anyConsonant + '+';
085    protected static final Pattern repeats = Pattern.compile("(.)\\1+"),
086            vowelClusters = Pattern.compile(anyVowelCluster, REFlags.IGNORE_CASE | REFlags.UNICODE),
087            consonantClusters = Pattern.compile(anyConsonantCluster, REFlags.IGNORE_CASE | REFlags.UNICODE);

099            vulgarChecks = new Pattern[]
100            {
101                    //17 is REFlags.UNICODE | REFlags.IGNORE_CASE
102                    Pattern.compile("[sξζzkкκcсς][hнlι].{1,3}[dtтτΓг]", 17),
103                    Pattern.compile("(?:(?:[pрρ][hн])|[fd]).{1,3}[kкκcсςxхжχq]", 17), // lots of these end in a 'k' sound, huh
104                    Pattern.compile("[kкκcсςСQq][uμυνvhн]{1,3}[kкκcсςxхжχqmм]", 17),
105                    Pattern.compile("[bъыбвβЪЫБ].?[iτιyуλγУ].?[cсς]", 17),
106                    Pattern.compile("[hн][^aаαΛeезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУ][^aаαΛeезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУ]?[rяΓ]", 17),
107                    Pattern.compile("[tтτΓгcсς][iτιyуλγУ][tтτΓг]+$", 17),
108                    Pattern.compile("(?:(?:[pрρ][hн])|f)[aаαΛhн]{1,}[rяΓ][tтτΓг]", 17),
109                    Pattern.compile("[Ssξζzcсς][hн][iτιyуλγУ].?[sξζzcсς]", 17),
110                    Pattern.compile("[aаαΛ][nи][aаαΛeезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУoоюσοuμυνv]{1,2}[Ssξlιζz]", 17),
111                    Pattern.compile("[aаαΛ]([sξζz]{2})", 17),
112                    Pattern.compile("[kкκcсςСQq][hн]?[uμυνv]([hн]?)[nи]+[tтτΓг]", 17),
113                    Pattern.compile("[nиfvν]..?[jg]", 17), // might as well remove two possible slurs and a body part with one check
114                    Pattern.compile("[pрρ](?:(?:([eезξεЗΣoоюσοuμυνv])\\1)|(?:[eезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУuμυνv]+[sξζz]))", 17), // the grab bag of juvenile words
115                    Pattern.compile("[mм][hнwψшщ]?..?[rяΓ].?d", 17), // should pick up the #1 obscenity from Spanish and French
116                    Pattern.compile("[g][hн]?[aаαАΑΛeеёзξεЕЁЗΕΣ][yуλγУeеёзξεЕЁЗΕΣ]", 17), // could be inappropriate for random text
117                    Pattern.compile("[wψшщuμυνv](?:[hн]?)[aаαΛeеёзξεЗΕΣoоюσοuμυνv](?:[nи]+)[gkкκcсςxхжχq]", 17)

410    /*
411     * Removes accented characters from a string; if the "base" characters are non-English anyway then the result won't
412     * be an ASCII string, but otherwise it probably will be.
413     * <br>
414     * Credit to user hashable from http://stackoverflow.com/a/1215117
415     *
416     * @param str a string that may contain accented characters
417     * @return a string with all accented characters replaced with their (possibly ASCII) counterparts
418     *
419    public String removeAccents(String str) {
420        String alteredString = Normalizer.normalize(str, Normalizer.Form.NFD);
421        alteredString = diacritics.matcher(alteredString).replaceAll("");
422        alteredString = alteredString.replace('æ', 'a');
423        alteredString = alteredString.replace('œ', 'o');
424        alteredString = alteredString.replace('Æ', 'A');
425        alteredString = alteredString.replace('Œ', 'O');
426        return alteredString;
427    }*/
428
429    /**
430     * Removes accented Latin-script characters from a string; if the "base" characters are non-English anyway then the
431     * result won't be an ASCII string, but otherwise it probably will be.
432     *
433     * @param str a string that may contain accented Latin-script characters
434     * @return a string with all accented characters replaced with their (possibly ASCII) counterparts
435     */
436    public static CharSequence removeAccents(CharSequence str) {
437        CharSequence alteredString = str;
438        for (int i = 0; i < accentFinders.length; i++) {
439            alteredString = accentFinders[i].replace(alteredString);
440        }
441        return alteredString;
442    }
443
444    private FakeLanguageGen register(String languageName) {
445        summary = registry.size() + "@1";
446        registry.put(languageName,this);
447        name = languageName;
448        return copy();
449    }
450
451    private FakeLanguageGen summarize(String brief) {
452        summary = brief;
453        return this;
454    }

800    /**
801     * Swahili is one of the more commonly-spoken languages in sub-Saharan Africa, and serves mainly as a shared language
802     * that is often learned after becoming fluent in one of many other (vaguely-similar) languages of the area. An
803     * example sentence in Swahili, that this might try to imitate aesthetically, is "Mtoto mdogo amekisoma," meaning
804     * "The small child reads it" (where it is a book). A notable language feature used here is the redoubling of words,
805     * which is used in Swahili to emphasize or alter the meaning of the doubled word; here, it always repeats exactly
806     * and can't make minor changes like a real language might. This generates things like "gata-gata", "hapi-hapi", and
807     * "mimamzu-mimamzu", always separating with a hyphen here.
808     * <br>
809     * As an aside, please try to avoid the ugly stereotypes that fantasy media often assigns to speakers of African-like
810     * languages when using this or any of the generators. Many fantasy tropes come from older literature written with
811     * major cultural biases, and real-world cultural elements can be much more interesting to players than yet another
812     * depiction of a "jungle savage" with stereotypical traits. Consider drawing from existing lists of real-world
813     * technological discoveries, like https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_Africa , for
814     * inspiration when world-building; though some groups may not have developed agriculture by early medieval times,
815     * their neighbors may be working iron and studying astronomy just a short distance away.
816     * <br>
817     * Kondueyu; ma mpiyamdabota mise-mise nizakwaja alamsa amja, homa nkajupomba.
818     */
819    public static final FakeLanguageGen SWAHILI = swahili().register("Swahili");

867     * associated with the text. One early comment this received was, "it looks like a bunch of letters semi-randomly
868     * thrown together", which is probably a typical response (the comment was made by someone fluent in German and

872     */

1230    /**
1231     * Imitation Hindi, romanized to use the Latin alphabet using accented glyphs similar to the IAST standard.
1232     * Most fonts do not support the glyphs that IAST-standard romanization of Hindi needs, so this uses alternate
1233     * glyphs from at most Latin Extended-A. Relative to the IAST standard, the glyphs {@code "ṛṝḷḹḍṭṅṇṣṃḥ"} become
1234     * {@code "ŗŕļĺđţńņşĕĭ"}, with the nth glyph in the first string being substituted with the nth glyph in the second
1235     * string. You may want to get a variant on this language with {@link #removeAccents()} if you can't display the
1236     * less-commonly-supported glyphs {@code āīūĕĭáíúóŗŕļţĺđńñņśş}. For some time SquidLib had a separate version of
1237     * imitation Hindi that was accurate to the IAST standard, but this version is more usable because font support is
1238     * much better for the glyphs it uses, so the IAST kind was removed (it added quite a bit of code for something that
1239     * was mostly unusable).
1240     * <br>
1241     * Darvāga yar; ghađhinopŕauka āĕrdur, conśaigaijo śabhodhaĕđū jiviđaudu.
1242     */
1243    public static final FakeLanguageGen HINDI_ROMANIZED = hindi().register("Hindi Romanized");

1284    /**
1285     * Imitation Arabic, using mostly the Latin alphabet but with some Greek letters for tough transliteration topics.
1286     * It's hard to think of a more different (widely-spoken) language to romanize than Arabic. Written Arabic does not
1287     * ordinarily use vowels (the writing system is called an abjad, in contrast to an alphabet), and it has more than a
1288     * few sounds that are very different from those in English. This version, because of limited support in fonts and
1289     * the need for separate words to be distinguishable with regular expressions, uses somewhat-accurate digraphs or
1290     * trigraphs instead of the many accented glyphs (not necessarily supported by most fonts) in most romanizations of
1291     * Arabic, and this scheme uses no characters from outside ASCII.
1292     * <br>
1293     * Please try to be culturally-sensitive about how you use this generator. Classical Arabic (the variant that
1294     * normally marks vowels explicitly and is used to write the Qur'an) has deep religious significance in Islam, and
1295     * if you machine-generate text that (probably) isn't valid Arabic, but claim that it is real, or that it has
1296     * meaning when it actually doesn't, that would be an improper usage of what this generator is meant to do. In a
1297     * fantasy setting, you can easily confirm that the language is fictional and any overlap is coincidental; an
1298     * example of imitation Arabic in use is the Dungeons and Dragons setting, Al-Qadim, which according to one account
1299     * sounds similar to a word in real Arabic (that does not mean anything like what the designer was aiming for). In a
1300     * historical setting, FakeLanguageGen is probably "too fake" to make a viable imitation for any language, and may
1301     * just sound insulting if portrayed as realistic. You may want to mix ARABIC_ROMANIZED with a very different kind
1302     * of language, like GREEK_ROMANIZED or RUSSIAN_AUTHENTIC, to emphasize that this is not a real-world language.
1303     * <br>
1304     * Hiijakki al-aafusiib rihit, ibn-ullukh aj shwisari!
1305     */
1306    public static final FakeLanguageGen ARABIC_ROMANIZED = arabic().register("Arabic Romanized");

1427    /**
1428     * Somewhat close to Old Norse, which is itself very close to Icelandic, so this uses Icelandic spelling rules. Not
1429     * to be confused with the language(s) of Norway, where the Norwegian languages are called norsk, and are further
1430     * distinguished into Bokmål and Nynorsk. This should not be likely to seem like any form of Norwegian, since it
1431     * doesn't have the a-with-ring letter 'å' and has the letters eth ('Ðð') and thorn ('Þþ'). If you want to remove
1432     * any letters not present on a US-ASCII keyboard, you can use {@link Modifier#SIMPLIFY_NORSE} on this language or
1433     * some mix of this with other languages; it also changes some of the usage of "j" where it means the English "y"
1434     * sound, making "fjord" into "fyord", which is closer to familiar uses from East Asia like "Tokyo" and "Pyongyang".
1435     * You can also now use {@link #NORSE_SIMPLIFIED} directly, which is probably easiest.
1436     * <br>
1437     * Leyrk tjör stomri kna snó æd ðrépdápá, prygso?
1438     */
1439    public static final FakeLanguageGen NORSE = norse().register("Norse");

1713     * evil"). The name INFERNAL refers to Dante's Inferno and the various naming conventions used for residents of Hell
1714     * in the more-modern Christian traditions (as well as some of the stylistic conventions of Old Testament figures
1715     * described as false idols, such as Moloch and Mammon). In an effort to make this distinct from the general style

1717     * humans), we add in vowel splits as used in LOVECRAFT and DEMONIC, then add quite a few accented vowels. These
1718     * traits make the language especially well-suited for "deal with the Devil" written bargains, where a single accent
1719     * placed incorrectly could change the meaning of a contract and provide a way for a fiend to gain leverage.
1720     * <br>
1721     * Zézîzûth eke'iez áhìphon; úhiah îbbëphéh haîtemheû esmez...
1722     */
1723    public static final FakeLanguageGen INFERNAL = infernal().register("Infernal");

1886    /**
1887     * Imitation text from an approximation of Korean, using the Revised Romanization method that is official in South
1888     * Korea today and is easier to type. The text this makes may be hard to pronounce. Korean is interesting as a
1889     * language to imitate for a number of reasons; many of the sounds in it are rarely found elsewhere, it can cluster
1890     * consonants rather tightly (most languages don't; English does to a similar degree but Japanese hardly has any
1891     * groups of consonants), and there are many more vowel sounds without using tones (here, two or three letters are
1892     * used for a vowel, where the first can be y or w and the rest can be a, e, i, o, or u in some combination). Some
1893     * letter combinations possible here are impossible or very rare in correctly-Romanized actual Korean, such as the
1894     * rare occurrence of a single 'l' before a vowel (it normally only appears in Romanized text before a consonant or
1895     * at the end of a word).
1896     * <br>
1897     * Hyeop euryam, sonyon muk tyeok aengyankeon, koelgwaelmwak.
1898     */
1899    public static final FakeLanguageGen KOREAN_ROMANIZED = korean().register("Korean Romanized");

2217    /**
2218     * Fantasy language based closely on {@link #DRAGON}, but with much shorter words normally and closing syllables
2219     * that may sound "rushed" or "crude", though it has the same general frequency of most consonants and vowels.
2220     * This means it still uses lots of "t", "k", and "r", can group two vowels sometimes, and when there's a consonant
2221     * in the middle of a word, it is often accompanied by an "r" on one or both sides. If used with
2222     * {@link NaturalLanguageCipher}, this will look very similar to DRAGON, because the syllable lengths aren't
2223     * determined by this object but by the text being ciphered. Still, the ends of words are often different. It is
2224     * called KOBOLD because, even though the original kobold myth was that of a goblin-like spirit that haunted cobalt
2225     * mines, the modern RPG treatment of kobolds frequently describes them as worshippers of dragons or in some way
2226     * created by dragons, but generally they're a sort of failure to live up to a dragon's high expectations. The feel
2227     * of this language is meant to be something like a dragon's speech, but much less "fancy" and rather curt.
2228     * <br>
2229     * Thritriz, laazak gruz kokak thon lut...
2230     */
2231    public static final FakeLanguageGen KOBOLD = new FakeLanguageGen(
2232            DRAGON.openingVowels, DRAGON.midVowels, DRAGON.openingConsonants, DRAGON.midConsonants, DRAGON.closingConsonants,
2233            new String[]{"ik", "ak", "ek", "at", "it", "ik", "ak", "ek", "at", "it", "ik", "ak", "ek", "at", "it", "et", "ut", "ark", "irk", "erk"},
2234            DRAGON.vowelSplitters, new int[]{1, 2, 3}, new double[]{5, 11, 1},
2235            0.1, 0.0, 0.0, 0.22, genericSanityChecks, true).register("Kobold");

2439    /**
2440     * Fantasy/sci-fi language that would potentially be fitting for a trade language spoken by various very-different
2441     * groups, such as creatures with tentacled faces who need to communicate with spider-elves and living crystals.
2442     * This language tries to use relatively few sounds so vocally-restricted species can speak it or approximate it,
2443     * but some of its sounds are uncommon. It uses "ng" as Vietnamese does, as a sound that can be approximated with
2444     * "w" but more accurately is like the sound at the end of "gong". It uses a breathy sound in many vowels,
2445     * represented by "h", and this is separate from (and can be combined with) lengthening the vowel by doubling it
2446     * ("a", "ah", "aa", and "aah" are different). The "x" sound can be approximated by any of the "kh" or "q" sounds
2447     * used in various human languages, or with its usage in English for "ks". This does separate some vowels with "'",
2448     * which can be a glottal stop as in Hawaiian or various other languages, or approximated with a brief pause.
2449     * <br>
2450     * Zrolmolurz, voluu, nguu yuh'ongohng!
2451     */
2452    public static final FakeLanguageGen DEEP_SPEECH = deepSpeech().register("Deep Speech");
2453    /**
2454     * Somewhat close to Old Norse, which is itself very close to Icelandic, but changed to avoid letters not on a
2455     * US-ASCII keyboard. Not to be confused with the language(s) of Norway, where the Norwegian languages are called
2456     * norsk, and are further distinguished into Bokmål and Nynorsk. This just applies {@link Modifier#SIMPLIFY_NORSE}
2457     * to {@link #NORSE}. This replaces eth ('Ðð') and thorn ('Þþ') with 'th' unless preceded by 's' (where 'sð' or 'sþ'
2458     * becomes "st") or followed by 'r' (where 'ðr' or 'þr' becomes 'fr'). It replaces 'Æ' or 'æ' with 'Ae' or 'ae', and
2459     * replaces 'Ö' or 'ö' with 'Ou' or "ou", which can change the length of a String relative to NORSE. It removes all
2460     * other accent marks (since the two-dot umlaut accent has already been changed, this only affects acute accents).
2461     * It also changes some of the usage of "j" where it means the English "y" sound, making "fjord" into "fyord", which
2462     * is closer to familiar uses from East Asia like "Tokyo" and "Pyongyang".
2463     * <br>
2464     * Leyrk tyour stomri kna sno aed frepdapa, prygso?
2465     */
2466    public static final FakeLanguageGen NORSE_SIMPLIFIED = norse().addModifiers(Modifier.SIMPLIFY_NORSE)
2467            .register("Norse Simplified");
2468

2622    /**
2623     * A rough imitation of the Crow language of the American Midwest, using some tone marks. Some of the orthography
2624     * rules aren't clear across Internet information about the language, so this really is a "fake" language it will be
2625     * generating, not the real thing at all. This considers 'x' to be the rough back-of-throat noise that isn't in
2626     * English other than in loanwords, like the Scottish "loch," and in names like the German "Bach." Doubled (to use
2627     * the linguistic term, geminated) consonants are pronounced for a longer time, and doubled vowels with the same
2628     * accent mark or no accent mark are also lengthened. An un-accented vowel has a normal tone, an accented vowel has
2629     * a high tone, and an accented vowel followed by an un-accented vowel has a falling tone. This last feature is the
2630     * least common among languages here, and is a good way of distinguishing imitation Crow from other languages.
2631     * <br>
2632     * Pashu-umíkiki; chinébúlu ak kóokutú shu-eníí-a ipíimúu heekokáakoku?
2633     */
2634    public static final FakeLanguageGen CROW = crow().register("Crow");

2972     * written with, using only the parts of the language that are usually written down. Some of the orthography
2973     * rules aren't clear across Internet information about the language, so this really is a "fake" language it will be
2974     * generating, not the real thing at all. The vowel 'ü' is used in place of the 'v' that the normal transliteration
2975     * uses, to help with profanity-checking what this generates; it is pronounced like in the French word "un".
2976     * <br>
2977     * Dah utugü tsahnahsütoi gohü usütahdi asi tsau dah tashi.
2978     */
2979    public static final FakeLanguageGen CHEROKEE_ROMANIZED = cherokee().register("Cherokee Romanized");

3072    /**
3073     * A very rough imitation of the Vietnamese language, without using the accurate characters Vietnamese really uses
3074     * but that are rare in fonts. Since so many letters in correct Vietnamese aren't available in most fonts, this
3075     * can't represent most of the accented vowels in the language, but it tries, with 6 accents for each of a, e, i, o,
3076     * and u, though none for y. It also uses 'ð' from Icelandic in place of the correct d with bar. This could also
3077     * maybe be used as an approximation of (badly) Romanized Thai, since Thai normally uses its own script but also has
3078     * many tones (which would be indicated by the accents here).
3079     * <br>
3080     * Bach trich, nŏ ngiukh nga cä tran ngonh... 
3081     */
3082    public static final FakeLanguageGen VIETNAMESE = vietnamese().register("Vietnamese");
3083
3084    /**
3085     * An array that stores all the hand-made FakeLanguageGen constants; it does not store randomly-generated languages
3086     * nor does it store modifications or mixes of languages. The order these are stored in is related to the numeric
3087     * codes for languages in the {@link #serializeToString()} output, but neither is dependent on the other if this
3088     * array is changed for some reason (which is not recommended, but not out of the question). If this is modified,
3089     * then it is probably a bad idea to assign null to any elements in registered; special care is taken to avoid null
3090     * elements in its original state, so some code may rely on the items being usable and non-null.
3091     */
3092    public static final FakeLanguageGen[] registered;
3093    public static final String[] registeredNames;
3094    static {
3095        // the first item in registry is null so it can be a placeholder for random languages; we want to skip it.
3096        registered = new FakeLanguageGen[registry.size()-1];
3097        registeredNames = new String[registered.length];
3098        for (int i = 0; i < registered.length; i++) {
3099            registeredNames[i] = registry.keyAt(i+1);
3100            registered[i] = registry.getAt(i+1);
3101        }
3102    }
3103
3104    /**
3105     * If a FakeLanguageGen is known and is in {@link #registered}, this allows you to look up that FakeLanguageGen by
3106     * name (using a name from {@link #registeredNames}).
3107     * @param name a String name such as "English", "Korean Romanized", or "Russian Authentic"
3108     * @return a FakeLanguageGen corresponding to the given name, or null if none was found
3109     */
3110    public static FakeLanguageGen get(String name)
3111    {
3112        return registry.get(name);
3113    }
3114    /**
3115     * If a FakeLanguageGen is known and is in {@link #registered}, this allows you to look up that FakeLanguageGen by
3116     * index, from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registered.length - 1}.
3117     * @param index an int from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registered.length - 1}
3118     * @return a FakeLanguageGen corresponding to the given index, or null if none was found
3119     */
3120    public static FakeLanguageGen getAt(int index)
3121    {
3122        return registry.getAt(index);
3123    }
3124    /**
3125     * If a FakeLanguageGen is known and is in {@link #registered}, this allows you to look up that FakeLanguageGen's
3126     * name by index, from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length - 1}.
3127     * @param index an int from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length - 1}
3128     * @return a FakeLanguageGen corresponding to the given index, or null if none was found
3129     */
3130    public static String nameAt(int index)
3131    {
3132        return registry.keyAt(index);
3133    }

3192    /**
3193     * This is a very complicated constructor! Maybe look at the calls to this to initialize static members of this
3194     * class, LOVECRAFT and GREEK_ROMANIZED.
3195     *
3196     * @param openingVowels        String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear at the start
3197     *                             of a word or in the middle; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3198     * @param midVowels            String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear in the
3199     *                             middle of the word; all openingVowels are automatically copied into this internally.
3200     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
3201     * @param openingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster that can appear
3202     *                             at the start of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3203     * @param midConsonants        String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
3204     *                             between vowels; all closingConsonants are automatically copied into this internally.
3205     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
3206     * @param closingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
3207     *                             at the end of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3208     * @param closingSyllables     String array where each element is a syllable starting with a vowel and ending in
3209     *                             whatever the word should end in; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3210     * @param vowelSplitters       String array where each element is a mark that goes between vowels, so if "-" is in this,
3211     *                             then "a-a" may be possible; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3212     * @param syllableLengths      int array where each element is a possible number of syllables a word can use; closely
3213     *                             tied to syllableFrequencies
3214     * @param syllableFrequencies  double array where each element corresponds to an element in syllableLengths and
3215     *                             represents how often each syllable count should appear relative to other counts; there
3216     *                             is no need to restrict the numbers to add up to any other number
3217     * @param vowelStartFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words start with vowels;
3218     *                             higher numbers yield more words starting with vowels
3219     * @param vowelEndFrequency    a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words end with vowels; higher
3220     *                             numbers yield more words ending in vowels
3221     * @param vowelSplitFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that, if vowelSplitters is not empty, determines how
3222     *                             often a vowel will be split into two vowels separated by one of those splitters
3223     * @param syllableEndFrequency a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often an element of
3224     *                             closingSyllables is used instead of ending normally
3225     */
3226    public FakeLanguageGen(String[] openingVowels, String[] midVowels, String[] openingConsonants,
3227                           String[] midConsonants, String[] closingConsonants, String[] closingSyllables, String[] vowelSplitters,
3228                           int[] syllableLengths, double[] syllableFrequencies, double vowelStartFrequency,
3229                           double vowelEndFrequency, double vowelSplitFrequency, double syllableEndFrequency) {
3230        this(openingVowels, midVowels, openingConsonants, midConsonants, closingConsonants, closingSyllables,
3231                vowelSplitters, syllableLengths, syllableFrequencies, vowelStartFrequency, vowelEndFrequency,
3232                vowelSplitFrequency, syllableEndFrequency, englishSanityChecks, true);
3233    }
3234
3235    /**
3236     * This is a very complicated constructor! Maybe look at the calls to this to initialize static members of this
3237     * class, LOVECRAFT and GREEK_ROMANIZED.
3238     *
3239     * @param openingVowels        String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear at the start
3240     *                             of a word or in the middle; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3241     * @param midVowels            String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear in the
3242     *                             middle of the word; all openingVowels are automatically copied into this internally.
3243     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
3244     * @param openingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster that can appear
3245     *                             at the start of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3246     * @param midConsonants        String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
3247     *                             between vowels; all closingConsonants are automatically copied into this internally.
3248     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
3249     * @param closingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
3250     *                             at the end of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3251     * @param closingSyllables     String array where each element is a syllable starting with a vowel and ending in
3252     *                             whatever the word should end in; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3253     * @param vowelSplitters       String array where each element is a mark that goes between vowels, so if "-" is in this,
3254     *                             then "a-a" may be possible; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3255     * @param syllableLengths      int array where each element is a possible number of syllables a word can use; closely
3256     *                             tied to syllableFrequencies
3257     * @param syllableFrequencies  double array where each element corresponds to an element in syllableLengths and
3258     *                             represents how often each syllable count should appear relative to other counts; there
3259     *                             is no need to restrict the numbers to add up to any other number
3260     * @param vowelStartFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words start with vowels;
3261     *                             higher numbers yield more words starting with vowels
3262     * @param vowelEndFrequency    a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words end with vowels; higher
3263     *                             numbers yield more words ending in vowels
3264     * @param vowelSplitFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that, if vowelSplitters is not empty, determines how
3265     *                             often a vowel will be split into two vowels separated by one of those splitters
3266     * @param syllableEndFrequency a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often an element of
3267     *                             closingSyllables is used instead of ending normally
3268     * @param sane                 true to perform sanity checks for pronounce-able sounds to most English speakers, replacing many
3269     *                             words that are impossible to say; slows down generation slightly, irrelevant for non-Latin alphabets
3270     * @param clean                true to perform vulgarity/obscenity checks on the word, replacing it if it is too close to a
3271     *                             common English vulgarity, obscenity, or slur/epithet; slows down generation slightly
3272     */
3273    public FakeLanguageGen(String[] openingVowels, String[] midVowels, String[] openingConsonants,
3274                           String[] midConsonants, String[] closingConsonants, String[] closingSyllables, String[] vowelSplitters,
3275                           int[] syllableLengths, double[] syllableFrequencies, double vowelStartFrequency,
3276                           double vowelEndFrequency, double vowelSplitFrequency, double syllableEndFrequency,
3277                           Pattern[] sane, boolean clean) {
3278        this.openingVowels = openingVowels;
3279        this.midVowels = new String[openingVowels.length + midVowels.length];
3280        System.arraycopy(midVowels, 0, this.midVowels, 0, midVowels.length);
3281        System.arraycopy(openingVowels, 0, this.midVowels, midVowels.length, openingVowels.length);
3282        this.openingConsonants = openingConsonants;
3283        this.midConsonants = new String[midConsonants.length + closingConsonants.length];
3284        System.arraycopy(midConsonants, 0, this.midConsonants, 0, midConsonants.length);
3285        System.arraycopy(closingConsonants, 0, this.midConsonants, midConsonants.length, closingConsonants.length);
3286        this.closingConsonants = closingConsonants;
3287        this.vowelSplitters = vowelSplitters;
3288        this.closingSyllables = closingSyllables;
3289
3290        this.syllableFrequencies = new double[syllableLengths[syllableLengths.length - 1]];
3291        double total = 0.0, bias = 0.0;
3292        for (int i = 0; i < syllableLengths.length; i++) {
3293            total += (this.syllableFrequencies[syllableLengths[i]-1] = syllableFrequencies[i]);
3294            bias += syllableLengths[i] * syllableFrequencies[i];
3295        }
3296        totalSyllableFrequency = total;
3297        syllableBias = bias / total;
3298        if (vowelStartFrequency > 1.0)
3299            this.vowelStartFrequency = 1.0 / vowelStartFrequency;
3300        else
3301            this.vowelStartFrequency = vowelStartFrequency;
3302        if (vowelEndFrequency > 1.0)
3303            this.vowelEndFrequency = 1.0 / vowelEndFrequency;
3304        else
3305            this.vowelEndFrequency = vowelEndFrequency;
3306        if (vowelSplitters.length == 0)
3307            this.vowelSplitFrequency = 0.0;
3308        else if (vowelSplitFrequency > 1.0)
3309            this.vowelSplitFrequency = 1.0 / vowelSplitFrequency;
3310        else
3311            this.vowelSplitFrequency = vowelSplitFrequency;
3312        if (closingSyllables.length == 0)
3313            this.syllableEndFrequency = 0.0;
3314        else if (syllableEndFrequency > 1.0)
3315            this.syllableEndFrequency = 1.0 / syllableEndFrequency;
3316        else
3317            this.syllableEndFrequency = syllableEndFrequency;
3318        this.clean = clean;
3319        sanityChecks = sane;
3320        modifiers = new ArrayList<>(4);
3321    }
3322
3323    private FakeLanguageGen(String[] openingVowels, String[] midVowels, String[] openingConsonants,
3324                            String[] midConsonants, String[] closingConsonants, String[] closingSyllables,
3325                            String[] vowelSplitters, double[] syllableFrequencies,
3326                            double vowelStartFrequency, double vowelEndFrequency, double vowelSplitFrequency,
3327                            double syllableEndFrequency, Pattern[] sanityChecks, boolean clean,
3328                            List<Modifier> modifiers) {
3329        this.openingVowels = copyStrings(openingVowels);
3330        this.midVowels = copyStrings(midVowels);
3331        this.openingConsonants = copyStrings(openingConsonants);
3332        this.midConsonants = copyStrings(midConsonants);
3333        this.closingConsonants = copyStrings(closingConsonants);
3334        this.closingSyllables = copyStrings(closingSyllables);
3335        this.vowelSplitters = copyStrings(vowelSplitters);
3336        this.syllableFrequencies = Arrays.copyOf(syllableFrequencies, syllableFrequencies.length);
3337        this.vowelStartFrequency = vowelStartFrequency;
3338        this.vowelEndFrequency = vowelEndFrequency;
3339        this.vowelSplitFrequency = vowelSplitFrequency;
3340        this.syllableEndFrequency = syllableEndFrequency;
3341        double total = 0.0, bias = 0.0;
3342        for (int i = 0; i < syllableFrequencies.length; i++) {
3343            total += syllableFrequencies[i];
3344            bias += (i + 1.0) * syllableFrequencies[i];
3345        }
3346        totalSyllableFrequency = total;
3347        syllableBias = bias / total;
3348        if (sanityChecks == null)
3349            this.sanityChecks = null;
3350        else {
3351            this.sanityChecks = new Pattern[sanityChecks.length];
3352            System.arraycopy(sanityChecks, 0, this.sanityChecks, 0, sanityChecks.length);
3353        }
3354        this.clean = clean;
3355        this.modifiers = new ArrayList<>(modifiers);
3356    }

3358    private static String[] processParts(OrderedMap<String, String> parts, Set<String> missingSounds,
3359                                         Set<String> forbidden, IRNG rng, double repeatSingleChance,
3360                                         int preferredLimit) {
3361        int l, sz = parts.size();
3362        List<String> working = new ArrayList<>(sz * 24);
3363        String pair;
3364        for (int e = 0; e < parts.size(); e++) {
3365            Map.Entry<String, String> sn = parts.entryAt(e);
3366            if (missingSounds.contains(sn.getKey()))
3367                continue;
3368            for (String t : sn.getValue().split(" ")) {
3369                if (forbidden.contains(t))
3370                    continue;
3371                l = t.length();
3372                int num;
3373                char c;
3374                switch (l) {
3375                    case 0:
3376                        break;
3377                    case 1:
3378                        working.add(t);
3379                        working.add(t);
3380                        working.add(t);
3381                        c = t.charAt(0);
3382                        num = 0;
3383                        boolean repeat = true;
3384                        switch (c) {
3385                            case 'w':
3386                                num += 2;
3387                            case 'y':
3388                            case 'h':
3389                                num += 4;
3390                            case 'q':
3391                            case 'x':
3392                                num += 4;
3393                                repeat = false;
3394                                break;
3395                            case 'i':
3396                            case 'u':
3397                                repeat = false;
3398                                num = 13;
3399                                break;
3400                            case 'z':
3401                            case 'v':
3402                                num = 4;
3403                                break;
3404                            case 'j':
3405                                num = 7;
3406                                break;
3407                            default:
3408                                if (e >= preferredLimit)
3409                                    num = 6;
3410                                else
3411                                    num = 13;
3412                        }
3413                        for (int i = 0; i < num * 3; i++) {
3414                            if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.75) {
3415                                working.add(t);
3416                            }
3417                        }
3418
3419                        if (repeat && rng.nextDouble() < repeatSingleChance) {
3420                            pair = t + t;
3421                            if (missingSounds.contains(pair))
3422                                continue;
3423                            working.add(pair);
3424                            working.add(pair);
3425                            working.add(pair);
3426                            if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.7) {
3427                                working.add(pair);
3428                                working.add(pair);
3429                            }
3430                            if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.7) {
3431                                working.add(pair);
3432                            }
3433                        }
3434
3435                        break;
3436                    case 2:
3437                        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.65) {
3438                            c = t.charAt(1);
3439                            switch (c) {
3440                                case 'z':
3441                                    num = 1;
3442                                    break;
3443                                case 'w':
3444                                    num = 3;
3445                                    break;
3446                                case 'n':
3447                                    num = 4;
3448                                    break;
3449                                default:
3450
3451                                    if (e >= preferredLimit)
3452                                        num = 2;
3453                                    else
3454                                        num = 7;
3455                            }
3456                            working.add(t);
3457                            for (int i = 0; i < num; i++) {
3458                                if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.25) {
3459                                    working.add(t);
3460                                }
3461                            }
3462                        }
3463                        break;
3464                    case 3:
3465                        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.5) {
3466                            c = t.charAt(0);
3467                            switch (c) {
3468                                case 'z':
3469                                    num = 1;
3470                                    break;
3471                                case 'w':
3472                                    num = 3;
3473                                    break;
3474                                case 'n':
3475                                    num = 4;
3476                                    break;
3477                                default:
3478                                    if (e >= preferredLimit)
3479                                        num = 2;
3480                                    else
3481                                        num = 6;
3482                            }
3483                            working.add(t);
3484                            for (int i = 0; i < num; i++) {
3485                                if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.2) {
3486                                    working.add(t);
3487                                }
3488                            }
3489                        }
3490                        break;
3491                    default:
3492                        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.3 && (t.charAt(l - 1) != 'z' || rng.nextDouble() < 0.1)) {
3493                            working.add(t);
3494                        }
3495                        break;
3496                }
3497            }
3498        }
3499        return working.toArray(new String[0]);
3500    }

3515    public static FakeLanguageGen randomLanguage(long seed) {
3516        GWTRNG rng = new GWTRNG(seed);
3517        int[] lengths = new int[rng.between(3, 5)];
3518        System.arraycopy(new int[]{1, 2, 3, 4}, 0, lengths, 0, lengths.length);
3519        double[] chances = new double[lengths.length];
3520        System.arraycopy(new double[]{
3521                5 + rng.nextDouble(4), 13 + rng.nextDouble(9), 3 + rng.nextDouble(3), 1 + rng.nextDouble(2)
3522        }, 0, chances, 0, chances.length);
3523        double vowelHeavy = rng.between(0.2, 0.5), removalRate = rng.between(0.15, 0.65);
3524        int sz = openCons.size();
3525        int[] reordering = rng.randomOrdering(sz), vOrd = rng.randomOrdering(openVowels.size());
3526        OrderedMap<String, String>
3527                parts0 = new OrderedMap<>(openVowels),
3528                parts1 = new OrderedMap<>(openCons),
3529                parts2 = new OrderedMap<>(midCons),
3530                parts3 = new OrderedMap<>(closeCons);
3531        OrderedSet<String> forbidden = new OrderedSet<>(1024, 0.25f), missingSounds = new OrderedSet<>(64, 0.875f);
3532        parts1.reorder(reordering);
3533        parts2.reorder(reordering);
3534        parts3.reorder(reordering);
3535        parts0.reorder(vOrd);
3536        int n;
3537
3538        int mn = Math.min(rng.nextInt(3), rng.nextInt(3)), sz0, p0s;
3539
3540        for (n = 0; n < mn; n++) {
3541            missingSounds.add(parts0.keyAt(0));
3542            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts0.getAt(0).split(" "));
3543            parts0.removeFirst();
3544        }
3545        p0s = parts0.size();
3546        sz0 = Math.max(rng.between(1, p0s + 1), rng.between(1, p0s + 1));
3547        char[] nextAccents = new char[sz0], unaccented = new char[sz0];
3548        int vowelAccent = rng.between(1, 7);
3549        for (int i = 0; i < sz0; i++) {
3550            nextAccents[i] = accentedVowels[vOrd[i + mn]][vowelAccent];
3551            unaccented[i] = accentedVowels[vOrd[i + mn]][0];
3552        }
3553        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.8) {
3554            for (int i = 0; i < sz0; i++) {
3555                char ac = nextAccents[i], ua = unaccented[i];
3556                String v = "", uas = String.valueOf(ua);
3557                Pattern pat = Pattern.compile("\\b([aeiou]*)(" + ua + ")([aeiou]*)\\b");
3558                Replacer rep = pat.replacer("$1$2$3 $1" + ac + "$3"), repLess = pat.replacer("$1" + ac + "$3");
3559                for (int j = 0; j < p0s; j++) {
3560                    String k = parts0.keyAt(j);
3561                    if (uas.equals(k)) // uas is never null, always length 1
3562                        v = parts0.getAt(j);
3563                    else {
3564                        String current = parts0.getAt(j);
3565                        String[] splits = current.split(" ");
3566                        for (int s = 0; s < splits.length; s++) {
3567                            if (forbidden.contains(uas) && splits[s].contains(uas))
3568                                forbidden.add(splits[s].replace(ua, ac));
3569                        }
3570                        parts0.put(k, rep.replace(current));
3571                    }
3572                }
3573                parts0.put(String.valueOf(ac), repLess.replace(v));
3574            }
3575        }
3576
3577        n = 0;
3578        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.75) {
3579            missingSounds.add("z");
3580            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("z").split(" "));
3581            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("z").split(" "));
3582            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("z").split(" "));
3583            n++;
3584        }
3585        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.82) {
3586            missingSounds.add("x");
3587            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("x").split(" "));
3588            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("x").split(" "));
3589            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("x").split(" "));
3590            n++;
3591        }
3592        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.92) {
3593            missingSounds.add("qu");
3594            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("qu").split(" "));
3595            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("qu").split(" "));
3596            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("qu").split(" "));
3597            n++;
3598        }
3599        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.96) {
3600            missingSounds.add("q");
3601            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("q").split(" "));
3602            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("q").split(" "));
3603            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("q").split(" "));
3604            n++;
3605        }
3606        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.97) {
3607            missingSounds.add("tl");
3608            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("tl").split(" "));
3609            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("tl").split(" "));
3610            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("tl").split(" "));
3611            n++;
3612        }
3613        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.86) {
3614            missingSounds.add("ph");
3615            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("ph").split(" "));
3616            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("ph").split(" "));
3617            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("ph").split(" "));
3618            n++;
3619        }
3620        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.94) {
3621            missingSounds.add("kh");
3622            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("kh").split(" "));
3623            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("kh").split(" "));
3624            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("kh").split(" "));
3625            n++;
3626        }
3627        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.96) {
3628            missingSounds.add("bh");
3629            missingSounds.add("dh");
3630            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("bh").split(" "));
3631            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("bh").split(" "));
3632            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("bh").split(" "));
3633            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("dh").split(" "));
3634            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("dh").split(" "));
3635            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("dh").split(" "));
3636            n++;
3637            n++;
3638        }
3639
3640        for (; n < sz * removalRate; n++) {
3641            missingSounds.add(parts1.keyAt(n));
3642            missingSounds.add(parts2.keyAt(n));
3643            missingSounds.add(parts3.keyAt(n));
3644            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.getAt(n).split(" "));
3645            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.getAt(n).split(" "));
3646            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.getAt(n).split(" "));
3647        }
3648
3649        return new FakeLanguageGen(
3650                processParts(parts0, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, 0.0, p0s),
3651                new String[]{},
3652                processParts(openCons, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, 0.0, 4096),
3653                processParts(midCons, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, (rng.nextDouble() * 3 - 0.75) * 0.4444, 4096),
3654                processParts(closeCons, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, (rng.nextDouble() * 3 - 0.75) * 0.2857, 4096),
3655                new String[]{},
3656                new String[]{}, lengths, chances, vowelHeavy, vowelHeavy * 1.8, 0.0, 0.0, genericSanityChecks, true).summarize("0#" + seed + "@1");
3657    }
3658
3659    protected static boolean checkAll(CharSequence testing, Pattern[] checks) {
3660        CharSequence fixed = removeAccents(testing);
3661        for (int i = 0; i < checks.length; i++) {
3662            if (checks[i].matcher(fixed).find())
3663                return false;
3664        }
3665        return true;
3666    }
3667
3668    /**
3669     * Checks a CharSequence, such as a String, against an overzealous vulgarity filter, returning true if the text
3670     * could contain vulgar elements or words that could seem vulgar or juvenile. The idea here is that false positives
3671     * are OK as long as there are very few false negatives (missed vulgar words). Does not check punctuation or numbers
3672     * that could look like letters.
3673     * @param testing the text, as a CharSequence such as a String, to check
3674     * @return true if the text could contain a vulgar or juvenile element; false if it probably doesn't
3675     */
3676    public static boolean checkVulgarity(CharSequence testing)
3677    {
3678        CharSequence fixed = removeAccents(testing);
3679        for (int i = 0; i < vulgarChecks.length; i++) {
3680            if (vulgarChecks[i].matcher(fixed).find())
3681            {
3682//                System.out.println(vulgarChecks[i]);
3683                return true;
3684            }
3685        }
3686        return false;
3687    }

3689    /**
3690     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen, using and changing the current seed.
3691     *
3692     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3693     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3694     */
3695    public String word(boolean capitalize) {
3696        return word(srng, capitalize);
3697    }

3699    /**
3700     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified long seed to use for a shared StatefulRNG.
3701     * If seed is the same, a FakeLanguageGen should produce the same word every time with this method.
3702     *
3703     * @param seed       the seed, as a long, to use for the randomized string building
3704     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3705     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3706     */
3707    public String word(long seed, boolean capitalize) {
3708        srng.setState(seed);
3709        return word(srng, capitalize);
3710    }
3711
3712    /**
3713     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified RNG.
3714     *
3715     * @param rng        the RNG to use for the randomized string building
3716     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3717     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3718     */
3719    public String word(IRNG rng, boolean capitalize) {
3720        while (true) {
3721            sb.setLength(0);
3722            ender.setLength(0);
3723
3724            double syllableChance = rng.nextDouble(totalSyllableFrequency);
3725            int syllables = 1, i = 0;
3726            for (int s = 0; s < syllableFrequencies.length; s++) {
3727                if(syllableChance < syllableFrequencies[s])
3728                {
3729                    syllables = s + 1;
3730                    break;
3731                } else
3732                {
3733                    syllableChance -= syllableFrequencies[s];
3734                }
3735            }
3736            if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelStartFrequency) {
3737                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3738                if (syllables == 1)
3739                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3740                else
3741                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3742                i++;
3743            } else {
3744                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingConsonants));
3745            }
3746            String close = "";
3747            boolean redouble = false;
3748            if (i < syllables) {
3749                if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3750                    close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3751                    if (close.contains("@") && (syllables & 1) == 0) {
3752                        redouble = true;
3753                        syllables >>= 1;
3754
3755                        //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3756                    }
3757                    if (!close.contains("@"))
3758                        ender.append(close);
3759                    else if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelEndFrequency) {
3760                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3761                        if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3762                            ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3763                                    .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3764                        }
3765                    }
3766                } else {
3767                    ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3768                    if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3769                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3770                                .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3771                    }
3772                    if (rng.nextDouble() >= vowelEndFrequency) {
3773                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3774                        if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3775                            close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3776                            if (close.contains("@") && (syllables & 1) == 0) {
3777                                redouble = true;
3778                                syllables >>= 1;
3779
3780                                //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3781                            }
3782                            if (!close.contains("@"))
3783                                ender.append(close);
3784                        }
3785                    }
3786                }
3787                i += vowelClusters.matcher(ender).findAll().count();
3788
3789            }
3790
3791            for (; i < syllables; i++) {
3792                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3793                if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3794                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3795                            .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3796                }
3797                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3798            }
3799
3800            sb.append(ender);
3801            if (redouble && i <= syllables + 1) {
3802                sb.append(close.replaceAll("@", sb.toString()));
3803            }
3804
3805            if (sanityChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, sanityChecks))
3806            {
3807                continue;
3808            }
3809
3810            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3811                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
3812            }
3813
3814            if (capitalize)
3815                sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
3816
3817            if (clean && !checkAll(sb, vulgarChecks))
3818            {
3819                continue;
3820            }
3821            return sb.toString();
3822        }
3823    }
3824
3825    /**
3826     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen with an approximate number of syllables using the specified long seed 
3827     * to use for a shared StatefulRNG.
3828     * If seed and the other parameters are the same, a FakeLanguageGen should produce the same word every time with
3829     * this method.
3830     *
3831     * @param seed       the seed, as a long, to use for the randomized string building
3832     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3833     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
3834     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3835     */
3836    public String word(long seed, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables) {
3837        srng.setState(seed);
3838        return word(srng, capitalize, approxSyllables);
3839    }

3852    /**
3853     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen with an approximate number of syllables using the specified long seed 
3854     * to use for a shared StatefulRNG. This takes an array of {@link Pattern} objects (from RegExodus, not
3855     * java.util.regex) that should match invalid outputs, such as words that shouldn't be generated in some context due
3856     * to vulgarity or cultural matters. If seed and the other parameters are the same, a FakeLanguageGen should produce
3857     * the same word every time with this method.
3858     *
3859     * @param seed       the seed, as a long, to use for the randomized string building
3860     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3861     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
3862     * @param additionalChecks an array of RegExodus Pattern objects that match invalid words (these may be additional vulgarity checks, for example)
3863     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3864     */
3865    public String word(long seed, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables, Pattern[] additionalChecks) {
3866        srng.setState(seed);
3867        return word(srng, capitalize, approxSyllables, additionalChecks);
3868    }

3870    /**
3871     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified RNG with an approximate number of syllables.
3872     * This takes an array of {@link Pattern} objects (from RegExodus, not java.util.regex) that should match invalid
3873     * outputs, such as words that shouldn't be generated in some context due to vulgarity or cultural matters.
3874     *
3875     * @param rng        the RNG to use for the randomized string building
3876     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3877     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
3878     * @param additionalChecks an array of RegExodus Pattern objects that match invalid words (these may be additional vulgarity checks, for example)
3879     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3880     */
3881    public String word(IRNG rng, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables, Pattern[] additionalChecks) {
3882        if (approxSyllables <= 0) {
3883            sb.setLength(0);
3884            sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3885            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3886                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
3887            }
3888            if (capitalize) sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
3889            return sb.toString();
3890        }
3891        while (true) {
3892            sb.setLength(0);
3893            ender.setLength(0);
3894            int i = 0;
3895            if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelStartFrequency) {
3896                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3897                if (approxSyllables == 1 && closingConsonants.length > 0)
3898                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3899                else if (midConsonants.length > 0)
3900                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3901                i++;
3902            } else if (openingConsonants.length > 0) {
3903                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingConsonants));
3904            }
3905            String close = "";
3906            boolean redouble = false;
3907            if (i < approxSyllables) {
3908                if (closingSyllables.length > 0 && rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3909                    close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3910                    if (close.contains("@") && (approxSyllables & 1) == 0) {
3911                        redouble = true;
3912                        approxSyllables = approxSyllables >> 1;
3913
3914                        //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3915                    }
3916                    if (!close.contains("@"))
3917                        ender.append(close);
3918                    else if (redouble && rng.nextDouble() < vowelEndFrequency) {
3919                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3920                        if (vowelSplitters.length > 0 && rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3921                            ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3922                                    .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3923                        }
3924                    }
3925                } else {
3926                    ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3927                    if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3928                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3929                                .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3930                    }
3931                    if (rng.nextDouble() >= vowelEndFrequency) {
3932                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3933                        if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3934                            close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3935                            if (close.contains("@") && (approxSyllables & 1) == 0) {
3936                                redouble = true;
3937                                approxSyllables = approxSyllables >> 1;
3938
3939                                //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3940                            }
3941                            if (!close.contains("@"))
3942                                ender.append(close);
3943                        }
3944                    }
3945                }
3946                i += vowelClusters.matcher(ender).findAll().count();
3947            }
3948
3949            for (; i < approxSyllables; i++) {
3950                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3951                if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3952                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3953                            .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3954                }
3955                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3956            }
3957
3958            sb.append(ender);
3959            if (redouble && i <= approxSyllables + 1) {
3960                sb.append(close.replaceAll("@", sb.toString()));
3961            }
3962
3963            if (sanityChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, sanityChecks))
3964                continue;
3965
3966            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3967                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
3968            }
3969
3970            if (clean && !checkAll(sb, vulgarChecks))
3971                continue;
3972
3973            if (additionalChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, additionalChecks))
3974                continue;
3975
3976            if (capitalize)
3977                sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
3978
3979            return sb.toString();
3980        }
3981    }

3983    /**
3984     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified StatefulRNG with an approximate number of
3985     * syllables, potentially setting the state of rng mid-way through the word to another seed from {@code reseeds}
3986     * more than once if the word is long enough. This overload is less likely to be used very often.
3987     *
3988     * @param rng        the StatefulRNG to use for the randomized string building
3989     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3990     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
3991     * @param reseeds an array or varargs of additional long seeds to seed {@code rng} with mid-generation 
3992     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3993     */
3994    public String word(IStatefulRNG rng, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables, long... reseeds) {
3995        if (approxSyllables <= 0) {
3996            sb.setLength(0);
3997            sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3998            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3999                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
4000            }
4001            if (capitalize) sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
4002            return sb.toString();
4003        }
4004        int numSeeds, fraction = 1;
4005        if (reseeds != null)
4006            numSeeds = Math.min(reseeds.length, approxSyllables - 1);
4007        else numSeeds = 0;
4008        while (true) {
4009            sb.setLength(0);
4010            ender.setLength(0);
4011            int i = 0;
4012            if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelStartFrequency) {
4013                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
4014                if (approxSyllables == 1)
4015                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
4016                else
4017                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
4018                i++;
4019            } else {
4020                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingConsonants));
4021            }
4022            String close = "";
4023            boolean redouble = false;
4024            if (i < approxSyllables) {
4025                if (numSeeds > 0 && i > 0 && i == approxSyllables * fraction / (1 + numSeeds))
4026                    rng.setState(reseeds[fraction++ - 1]);
4027                if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
4028                    close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
4029                    if (close.contains("@") && (approxSyllables & 1) == 0) {
4030                        redouble = true;
4031                        approxSyllables = approxSyllables >> 1;
4032                    }
4033                    if (!close.contains("@"))
4034                        ender.append(close);
4035                    else if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelEndFrequency) {
4036                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
4037                        if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
4038                            ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
4039                                    .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
4040                        }
4041                    }
4042                } else {
4043                    ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
4044                    if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
4045                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
4046                                .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
4047                    }
4048                    if (rng.nextDouble() >= vowelEndFrequency) {
4049                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
4050                        if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
4051                            close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
4052                            if (close.contains("@") && (approxSyllables & 1) == 0) {
4053                                redouble = true;
4054                                approxSyllables = approxSyllables >> 1;
4055
4056                                //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
4057                            }
4058                            if (!close.contains("@"))
4059                                ender.append(close);
4060                        }
4061                    }
4062                }
4063                i += vowelClusters.matcher(ender).findAll().count();
4064            }
4065
4066            for (; i < approxSyllables; i++) {
4067                if (numSeeds > 0 && i > 0 && i == approxSyllables * fraction / (1 + numSeeds))
4068                    rng.setState(reseeds[fraction++ - 1]);
4069                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
4070                if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
4071                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
4072                            .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
4073                }
4074                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
4075            }
4076
4077            sb.append(ender);
4078            if (redouble && i <= approxSyllables + 1) {
4079                sb.append(close.replaceAll("@", sb.toString()));
4080            }
4081
4082            if (sanityChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, sanityChecks))
4083                continue;
4084
4085            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
4086                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
4087            }
4088
4089            if (capitalize)
4090                sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
4091
4092            if (clean && !checkAll(sb, vulgarChecks))
4093                continue;
4094            return sb.toString();
4095        }
4096    }

4186    /**
4187     * Generate a sentence from this FakeLanguageGen using the specific RNG. The sentence's length in
4188     * words will be between minWords and maxWords, both inclusive. It will put one of the punctuation Strings from
4189     * {@code midPunctuation} between two words (before the space) at a frequency of {@code midPunctuationFrequency}
4190     * (between 0 and 1), and will end the sentence with one String chosen from {@code endPunctuation}.
4191     *
4192     * @param rng                     the RNG to use for the randomized string building
4193     * @param minWords                an int for the minimum number of words in a sentence; should be at least 1
4194     * @param maxWords                an int for the maximum number of words in a sentence; should be at least equal to minWords
4195     * @param midPunctuation          a String array where each element is a comma, semicolon, or the like that goes before a
4196     *                                space in the middle of a sentence
4197     * @param endPunctuation          a String array where each element is a period, question mark, or the like that goes at
4198     *                                the very end of a sentence
4199     * @param midPunctuationFrequency a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often Strings from
4200     *                                midPunctuation should be inserted before spaces
4201     * @return a sentence in the fake language as a String
4202     */
4203    public String sentence(IRNG rng, int minWords, int maxWords, String[] midPunctuation, String[] endPunctuation,
4204                           double midPunctuationFrequency) {
4205        if (minWords < 1)
4206            minWords = 1;
4207        if (minWords > maxWords)
4208            maxWords = minWords;
4209        if (midPunctuationFrequency > 1.0) {
4210            midPunctuationFrequency = 1.0 / midPunctuationFrequency;
4211        }
4212        ssb.setLength(0);
4213        ssb.ensureCapacity(12 * maxWords);
4214        ssb.append(word(rng, true));
4215        for (int i = 1; i < minWords; i++) {
4216            if (rng.nextDouble() < midPunctuationFrequency) {
4217                ssb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midPunctuation));
4218            }
4219            ssb.append(' ').append(word(rng, false));
4220        }
4221        for (int i = minWords; i < maxWords && rng.nextInt(2 * maxWords) > i; i++) {
4222            if (rng.nextDouble() < midPunctuationFrequency) {
4223                ssb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midPunctuation));
4224            }
4225            ssb.append(' ').append(word(rng, false));
4226        }
4227        if (endPunctuation != null && endPunctuation.length > 0)
4228            ssb.append(rng.getRandomElement(endPunctuation));
4229        return ssb.toString();
4230    }
